Something changed.    She looks amazing after being away from the company for a few weeks, starting a new job, seeing someone that sounds like a really nice guy, and lord knows what else that is going on in her life.

The difference in her face and her stance was immediately apparent.   She looked as though she was living in a better world compared to not even a month ago.  It can all be summed up with a single word.   She looks HAPPY.

I wish everyone that I know could go through such a transformation.   I only wish they didn't have to go through the difficulties that she has experienced over the past few months to get there.



Now I am starting to look at myself in the mirror and I see dark circles under my eyes....  more than a few pounds overweight....  tired enough that i can't get to sleep....   perpetual headaches, and anxiety that fuels nervous energy.    I know a few things, but what else will I need to do to experience such an uplifting change for myself?

Just this week, as I was grabbing a quick lunch from a fast food joint...

I was standing behind a "little old lady" at the self-serve soda fountain. She wasn't moving very quickly, which I didn't mind since I had plenty of time for lunch that day. She said Hello and apologized for taking so long when she turned around.

"That's okay, I'm trying to pick something. I don't like all the sugar in these drinks. I think I'll just get some iced tea." I replied, trying to be polite.

In her little old lady voice and with a straight face she said "Iced tea is good for you. It helps you poop."

I have been telling people about that all week long


NOTE:  I rewrote this entry after using the story as a comment on the Serious Eats Food blog.

I am moved to say that pleasing a woman orally is one of my favorite things.  For that matter, pleasing a man rates right up there too. 

Listening to the song has me thinking.  Thinking and remembering the last time I was with a woman that appreciated the pleasure I so love to give.   A woman that knows how to receive the sensual touch that a tongue can provide.    She knows how to share her desires and to direct the attention I long to give again.

It has been far to long since I was with someone willing to surrender their flesh to my attention.  There have been many nights spent dreaming about just this, taking my time and bringing a partner to the brink of release and then back down so the pleasure can be prolonged as long as possible.   Lately the dreams are about evenly split between pleasuring men and women and that suits me just fine.

I will admit  that I get more intense pleasure myself through the act of pleasing another.   The plain truth is that I have never in my life experienced an orgasm from receiving oral sex.   It has been close a few times, but never quite there.    On the other hand I have helped several different partners achieve intense orgasms through my attentions.   Sometimes I wonder how it is that I can feel so intensely while using my mouth on someone else, but then so little when on the receiving end of things. 

Maybe I am being selfish, wanting to find someone that enjoys sex as much as I.

http://cinebeats.blogsome.com/2007/12/29/lattitude-zero-1969/

In 1969 the movie "Latitude Zero" was released. Directed by Ishiro Honda (Godzilla, Rodan, etc.), the Japanese movie with American actors was the very first movie I was allowed to see at the theater - sans parents.  A half dozen of my cousins and I went to see the movie at the Strand theater in Kalispell, Montana.   One of two theaters in the town, the Strand was geared towards younger crowds.  Family oriented films would be shown at the Strand while the adult themed movies were screened at the theater across the street.   I honestly can't remember the name of the other theater.  It was the Royal, or Grand, or something along those lines.

Latitude Zero was recently released on DVD and I was able to watch it this weekend.  I remembered more about the movie than I expected. From the gold outfits to the glove weapons the details were as clear to me as if I had seen it just a few days before.    The submarines were even more fantastic than I had remembered though.

This film was the start of my lifelong love of movies and science fiction in general.  Less than a decade later Star Wars was released and I watched it for the first time in the same theater.    Sure, Star Wars was a very important film for all sci-fi fans, but Latitude Zero was my first.   You always remember your first.

I have been searching for over twenty years.   Finally, through a Sci-Fi Classic Nostalgia page in a magazine I found it...  Marine Boy.

I watched this cartoon when it was shown on a Canadian television channel during my childhood.   I clearly remember certain details such as the sonic boomerang, oxygum, the patrol ship, and the white dolphin.   I don't remember any of the episodes or other characters, but the images that I do remember have haunted me for many years.  

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_Boy

http://www.thechestnut.com/marine.htm

Over the years I have asked many people if they remembered a cartoon about the boy who swims under water and eats oxygen gum.  Most of the time I was met with blank stares.   Once in a while a smile would appear and we would reminisce about a childhood memory.  No-one ever came up with the right name of the show.   I did hear the name Aqua-Boy a few times but was never able to find anything searching on that term.  

I wouldn't say that I was obsessed with the memory.  But whenever someone would seem to be a cartoon fan, or the conversation would turn to remembering old television shows, I would ask about the boy who swims under water.   I knew that someday it would result in finding the answer.  

Today I know the answer.  Today I feel like a kid again.

An akita puppy came to the house on Saturday.  It was a test of how well a dog might fit into our household.

The dominant cat in the house, Tuxedo, was immediately traumatized when Tora came into the house.    Tux had just started to head for the door when Tora came in and said hello in the way that puppies do, by reaching out and seeing what happens.   Tux freaked.   He hissed, moaned, growled, and ran.  Not necessarily in that order.

I tried to force Tux off his perch to disastrous result.  He held on to the carpeted landing and my footing was lost on the recliner and as I pulled and he pulled it ended up with me falling.   Tux fell in between the recliner and the end table and after a few minutes of chaos he leapt back to his perch.    

Not being one to leave things alone, I persisted and walked behind the furniture and finally pulled Tux from his vantage point above the room.   I took him to the basement where he could relax without having to see Tora.

After a while Tux came back to the main floor and we all sat in the sun room.   Tux begrudgingly sat on the couch being petted, growling all the while, as Tora continued to explore and play with the cat toys.

Up to that point I think things went as well as was possible given the way the two animals met.    I could've controlled that meeting a little better but the first impression was made and can't be undone.

The rest of the weekend wasn't as pleasant.  It seems as though Tuxedo has decided to reassert his dominance over the household.  The upstairs cat, Lilly, is in fear now as Tux is making it clear that he is in charge.   Tux has broken through the gate that separates the two cats and Lilly has lost more than a little fur over the last few days.    

Once Tuxedo feels as though he is in control again things will start to return to normal.  I hope it doesn't take too long.  I like to sleep at night.

Sometimes you find something on the internet that perfectly expresses your own thoughts.

  Today I found just such a thing.

It affects me deeply when those around me are in pain.   My closest friend is going through a painful time right now and I feel it more deeply than if it were my own.

The last thing I think about at night is my friend. 

The first thing I think about in the morning is my friend.

Throughout the day I think about her and wish I could ball up everything that is bad and hide it from her even for a short while.

She deserves much better than is happening, but I know that she will make it through because she is also one of the brightest and strongest people I know.

Were it not for her I would probably not be here today.  She has a greater impact for me than she probably knows, and I will do anything for her.

My heart aches.  My mind reels.  My soul yearns to be able to help her through this time.

And the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom.
Anais Nin
US (French-born) author & diarist (1903 - 1977)

I am currently using less than 1% of the 4GB of space allocated in my GMAIL account.  I don't save much of the mail that I receive.    In total I have less than 200 messages archived.   On the other hand, in the past day I have accumulated over 3,000 SPAM messages.    I emptied the spam folder yesterday just after lunch.     I still glance through the spam folder looking for legitimate messages before clicking on the link to purge.  It takes more time to glance over the 3000 messages than it does to actually read all of the legitimate email.

I can't even imagine how much space this would take If this were hardcopy rather than electronic mail.

You Are 45% Left Brained, 55% Right Brained
The left side of your brain controls verbal ability, attention to detail, and reasoning. Left brained people are good at communication and persuading others. If you're left brained, you are likely good at math and logic. Your left brain prefers dogs, reading, and quiet. The right side of your brain is all about creativity and flexibility. Daring and intuitive, right brained people see the world in their unique way. If you're right brained, you likely have a talent for creative writing and art. Your right brain prefers day dreaming, philosophy, and sports.

It was a great day today.    The best birthday I have had in the last 10 years.    I didn't plan to do anything special or anticipate anything in particular.  When I woke up this morning I decided that I would have a nice day.  I wouldn't let anything bother me since today was my day.  I just wanted to have a day where I didn't think badly of myself.  I had that day.   Feeling food about myself for the entire day was my gift to myself.

Before the morning huddle I was visited by Christine.  She had balloons and the largest gift bag I have ever seen.   After arranging the balloons in my cube so they could be seen by everyone I opened the two gifts that were in the bag.  The first was a pair of black Vans shoes with koi designs in white.  Very Very cool.  I remember her asking about shoe size the other day, and I didn't pick up on it.    The second gift was a purple-ish t-shirt with a fantastic design depicting a kimono clad skeleton clutching a Japanese parasol and standing in a patch of white flowers.   Again a perfect match for my taste and I love it.

When I tried on the shoes at work I was so tickled that I wore them the entire day.    Every time I looked down and saw them I felt giddy inside.  As much as I like the design of the shoes it is the thought and care that went into selecting the shoes, even to the point of asking my shoe size in a way that totally went over my head.  It has been a long time since anyone put that much thought into something for me.  

I changed into the shirt after making it home and it fits very well.    I plan on heading to the same store to find other shirts by the same manufacturer.   Again this is a gift that was very well thought out and I am touched.   Christine knows me very well.


Today has been a very good day.    I can't imagine it being any better.

3 minute video from a Prison Food Convention. The quote I find most interesting is that the nutritional requirements for prison food are higher than the requirements for school lunch programs. I don't know if it is true, but I find it interesting. found via Boing Boing.

The U.S. Mint has unveiled the design for the new $5 bill.




I am all for improving the security of our currency.   I also know that paper money will likely never* be completely replaced by electronic transfer.   But... purple?  PURPLE!








* Never is a very long time.  In this context I should probably say "never in my lifetime" or "not for the forseeable future" or even "when pigs fly
Miracle Beer Diet - Click here for another funny movie.

I watched two different Highlander movies this week.

The first, Highlander: The Search for Vengance, is an animated adventure which was actually quite good.  The plot was straightforward and the story telling followed the Highlander formula without being too tied down by it.    The animation was consistent although not beautiful.   The story follows Colin MacLeod as he fights through a post-apocalyptic landscape seeking revenge for the murder of a lover.

The second movie, Highlander: The Source, is a made-for-TV movie starring Adrian Paul.  I wish I could find something good to say about this movie.  The movie is live-action over questionable CGI in a post-apocalyptic world which finds several immortals seeking the source of their immortality.    I sat through the entire movie hoping for some sort of payoff, only to be cheated in the end.   I can only hope that the actors were payed well since they will all have to suffer this work on their resume.

There can be only one... and  Highlander II: The Quickening is no longer the worst movie in the series.

First I have to say that I do not write well and I do not have any illusions to the contrary.  My writing may have improved over the last year due to the inspiration and support of a very good friend.   She, on the other hand, is a fabulous writer and I hope that she continues to write for a long time.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="27" />

I grew up in an house where both kinds of music was heard...  Country AND Western.   All kidding aside, my parents were fans of country music.  When we would go to the Dixie Inn, a local diner, I would be given a couple of nickels to play seven songs on the jukebox.   Conway Twitty, Pasty Cline, Loretta Lynn and other country music greats were always on the play list.   

Those, of course, were my parent's favorite artists and I liked them through training.  I still enjoy the country classics and always will.

I came into my own musical tastes during the early seventies.   We were at the laundromat and "Witchy Woman" started playing on the radio.  The music was country enough that my mom liked it and agreed to buy me the 8-track cassette by The Eagles.    From there I branched out into other soft rock and eventually discovered harder sounds by The Doors, Black Sabbath, Nazareth and more.

When Kiss hit the scene I was immediately hooked.  Although the music wasn't complex the energy and theatrics were just what I was looking for.   I joined the Kiss Army with full knowledge that it would drive my parents crazy.  

As embarrassing as it is today, I admit that my first favorite band was Kiss.
This journal is going to change.  I don't quite know what the end result will be yet, but the change is coming.
